title: How to Create and Work a Juxl Puzzle

steps.headline: Draw four groups of three lines each.
steps.description: Leave some space between the lines. You can put the groups anywhere on the page, facing any direction, but it will help to leave plenty of space both between the lines and between and around the groups.

steps.headline: Draw a curve between the end of any line with the end of any line in another group.
steps.description: Place dots at both ends of the curve.

steps.headline: Draw another curve between the end of any line and the end of any line in another group.
On the second curve only, place a dot anywhere between the two endpoints.
steps.description: Draw a third curve connecting this point with either end of any line in a group that the second curve does not touch. This completes your first move.

steps.headline: Continue making subsequent moves in this pattern.
steps.description: One curve between open endpoints in two different groups. A second curve between open endpoints in two different groups. A third curve between any point on the second curve and any open endpoint of another group.

steps.headline: Do, if necessary, run the curves between the lines or snake them around anywhere else on the page.
steps.description: If you intend to embellish your Juxl as an art piece later, you may want to try to take up the whole card and add interest to the shapes of the curves.

steps.headline: Win the game by connecting all the open line ends with curves, according to the pattern of moves.
If you wish, embellish your Juxl to create your own pocket-sized artwork.
steps.description: Depending on the techniques and colors you use, you can achieve a wide range of effects.

steps.headline: Create harder Juxls and more intricate designs by adding additional groups of lines at the beginning:
steps.description: Easy Level: Start with four groups of 3 lines each. Medium Level: Start with five groups of 4 lines each. Hard Level: Start with seven groups of 6 lines each.

text: Draw four groups of three lines each. Leave some space between the lines. You can put the groups anywhere on the page, facing any direction, but it will help to leave plenty of space both between the lines and between and around the groups. Draw a curve between the end of any line with the end of any line in another group. Place dots at both ends of the curve. Draw another curve between the end of any line and the end of any line in another group.  On the second curve only, place a dot anywhere between the two endpoints. Draw a third curve connecting this point with either end of any line in a group that the second curve does not touch. This completes your first move. Continue making subsequent moves in this pattern. One curve between open endpoints in two different groups. A second curve between open endpoints in two different groups. A third curve between any point on the second curve and any open endpoint of another group. Do not cross the curves.  Do, if necessary, run the curves between the lines or snake them around anywhere else on the page. If you intend to embellish your Juxl as an art piece later, you may want to try to take up the whole card and add interest to the shapes of the curves. Win the game by connecting all the open line ends with curves, according to the pattern of moves.  If you wish, embellish your Juxl to create your own pocket-sized artwork. Depending on the techniques and colors you use, you can achieve a wide range of effects. Create harder Juxls and more intricate designs by adding additional groups of lines at the beginning:  Easy Level: Start with four groups of 3 lines each. Medium Level: Start with five groups of 4 lines each. Hard Level: Start with seven groups of 6 lines each.
